p: The experimental results showed that ailanthone has a powerful herbicidal and post-emergence effect, which can be compared to synthetic herbicides such as glyphosate and paraquat [ 165]. Its disadvantages include low selectivity and rapid degradation by soil microorganisms. It turned out to be toxic for both weeds and crops, both for monocots and dicots (to a greater extent), but some species from the Malvaceae family such as cotton ( Gossypium hirsutum) and velvet leaf ( Abutilon theophrasti) proved to be resistant [ 165]. Due to microbial activity, the ailanthone lost phytotoxicity after five days in normal soil, but kept it high for 21 days in sterile soil [ 165]. The rapid decomposition of ailanthone was also confirmed in field conditions [ 170]. Low persistence is beneficial from an environmental point of view, but it requires repeated treatments during the growing season.
